content: heres my issue and question. i have been dubbed with severe testicular nerve damage and due to medication not working to resolve the issue, i have just completed my "trial stim period" for a spinal stimulator. with this they insert wire leads into the nerves around the spinal cord and through an external stimulator, they emit an electrical current to the nerves which blocks the pain from registering in the brain. i will soon be getting the permanant version which they implant under the skin to eleminate the external wiring. now to my question.. i love the army and wish to remain in and the doctor says that between 50-70% pain reduction is all that this will be able to provide and might need to remain on pain medication even after it is inserted. granted, this is a major improvement and i would take 5% and be happy if thats all it could do but again i am concerned that this will affect my career. i am wondering if anyone has this procedure and still remain active duty. i am aware of reclassing but a desk job really isnt my cup of tea. i was very physical in life until the pain was this severe back in september. the drawback is some doctors say to avoid physically demanding activities due to the leads pulling out of there anchoring, so sadly i dont know if surfing and snowboarding are out of my life now. if anyone can help it is deeply appreciated. thanks in advance.

content: quote: Originally posted by 88miker: heres my issue and question. i have been dubbed with severe testicular nerve damage and due to medication not working to resolve the issue, i have just completed my "trial stim period" for a spinal stimulator. with this they insert wire leads into the nerves around the spinal cord and through an external stimulator, they emit an electrical current to the nerves which blocks the pain from registering in the brain. i will soon be getting the permanant version which they implant under the skin to eleminate the external wiring. now to my question.. i love the army and wish to remain in and the doctor says that between 50-70% pain reduction is all that this will be able to provide and might need to remain on pain medication even after it is inserted. granted, this is a major improvement and i would take 5% and be happy if thats all it could do but again i am concerned that this will affect my career. i am wondering if anyone has this procedure and still remain active duty. i am aware of reclassing but a desk job really isnt my cup of tea. i was very physical in life until the pain was this severe back in september. the drawback is some doctors say to avoid physically demanding activities due to the leads pulling out of there anchoring, so sadly i dont know if surfing and snowboarding are out of my life now. if anyone can help it is deeply appreciated. thanks in advance. Miker, Given what you've written here, it's entirely possible you'll be boarded out. You STILL have the condition that is causing you the pain, the stim only "short circuits" it. Plus the fact that strenuous activty CAN dislodge the electodes, it doesn't bode well. Good Luck, however.

In my case, when I was on oxyconton for my leg injuries, for my job in Federal Law Enforcement, I was not allowed to carry any firearms while on that medication. Hope somehow things work out better for you. God...I miss that job!!! Don

content: well right now im on some pretty heavy stuff. i dont want to go to far into detail but one of them is morphine on a time release. others are your typical narcoticpain meds which i hate taking. i am really bummed out about this but luckily i have a great doctor whos goal is to be able to help me to lead a less painful life and "function" again if you catch my drift. im not going to lie, that gets me pretty depressed.. not suicidal just frustrated and right now im just taking it day by day.

title: Spinal Stimulator

content: Wow! - - I had back surgery while still in the military to correct a mashed disc and remove stalactite-like bone spurs which were digging into my sciatic nerves, causing me severe pain 24/7 and robbing me the use of my right leg (as well as any desire to go on living). The surgery, done arthroscopically, left about a 2 inch scar in the small of my back, required no bolts, screws or plates, and has completely free me of pain in that region, while restoring all use of my legs - - I remained 100% in the military, taking on not less, but more of a load. I have a son who has gone through an almost identical situation, and he is still on active duty - - I now have a lot of upper back pain between the shoulder blades because of similar problems. Doctors are less enthusiastic about surgery these days, so I do 8 arthritis tylenol a day - - The back surgery, not the same as yours obviously, gave me back an active life and kept me fully capable in the military. It did the same for my son. Both of us had nerves being crushed by a combination of sports-caused exertion/injury and bone spurs...both of which could be corrected with minimal surgery - - Maybe you? Wandering and Wondering
reply: Wow! - - I had back surgery while still in the military to correct a mashed disc and remove stalactite-like bone spurs which were digging into my sciatic nerves, causing me severe pain 24/7 and robbing me the use of my right leg (as well as any desire to go on living). The surgery, done arthroscopically, left about a 2 inch scar in the small of my back, required no bolts, screws or plates, and has completely free me of pain in that region, while restoring all use of my legs - - I remained 100% in the military, taking on not less, but more of a load. I have a son who has gone through an almost identical situation, and he is still on active duty - - I now have a lot of upper back pain between the shoulder blades because of similar problems. Doctors are less enthusiastic about surgery these days, so I do 8 arthritis tylenol a day - - The back surgery, not the same as yours obviously, gave me back an active life and kept me fully capable in the military. It did the same for my son. Both of us had nerves being crushed by a combination of sports-caused exertion/injury and bone spurs...both of which could be corrected with minimal surgery - - Maybe you? Wandering and Wondering

content: 88miker - If your physician and company commander agree that your condition/situation requires complex case management and will, in general, take about 6 months or more to resolve, then you can be recommended for transfer into a Warrior Transition Unit (WTU). The physician has to write a memo, the Company Commander has to complete a functional assessment, plus some other assorted paperwork, then it's all sent for review and possible assignment/attachment to a WTU near you. Being assigned/attached to a WTU is NOT a one-way ticket out. The idea of a WTU is to allow Soldiers to concentrate on healing and recovering maximum function. Being at maximum possible function can mean returning to duty (same MOS), MEB, PEB or MMRB for reclass. If you are having difficulty performing your job, and if you are having difficulty making medical appointments because of job requirements (or interference), then you might want to look into the WTU as an option that can give you a really good shot at staying in.
reply: 88miker - If your physician and company commander agree that your condition/situation requires complex case management and will, in general, take about 6 months or more to resolve, then you can be recommended for transfer into a Warrior Transition Unit (WTU). The physician has to write a memo, the Company Commander has to complete a functional assessment, plus some other assorted paperwork, then it's all sent for review and possible assignment/attachment to a WTU near you. Being assigned/attached to a WTU is NOT a one-way ticket out. The idea of a WTU is to allow Soldiers to concentrate on healing and recovering maximum function. Being at maximum possible function can mean returning to duty (same MOS), MEB, PEB or MMRB for reclass. If you are having difficulty performing your job, and if you are having difficulty making medical appointments because of job requirements (or interference), then you might want to look into the WTU as an option that can give you a really good shot at staying in.

title: Spinal Stimulator

content: Miker, Sorry to hear about your condition. I had a compression fracture to L3 vertebrae while in. I was down for 6 weeks. I was fine for awhile, but a few years later it started agrivating me. It got to the point where I was unable to do daily PT. I was waived from that but still had to perform the biannual PT Test. I progressively became slower and slower, but still not failing. Even then there was one doc that tried to get me Med Boarded. I was REAL lucky that I had 18 1/2 years in at the time he tried this. I was able to retire with my 20, but had to fight for it. I can't tell you what will happen to you as each case is different, but good luck. George P.S. - You may have already asked (and probably don't want to hear this) but have you asked the dreaded question of what your condition would be if they were removed. I know, I know, not what you want to hear. Just a question though...which is more important to you right now, the twins or your career...food for thought.
reply: Miker, Sorry to hear about your condition. I had a compression fracture to L3 vertebrae while in. I was down for 6 weeks. I was fine for awhile, but a few years later it started agrivating me. Even then there was one doc that tried to get me Med Boarded. I was REAL lucky that I had 18 1/2 years in at the time he tried this. I was able to retire with my 20, but had to fight for it. I can't tell you what will happen to you as each case is different, but good luck. George P.S. - You may have already asked (and probably don't want to hear this) but have you asked the dreaded question of what your condition would be if they were removed. I know, I know, not what you want to hear. Just a question though...which is more important to you right now, the twins or your career...food for thought.
title: Spinal Stimulator

content: Miker ... I like many others here have had a couple back surgeries. Now I have a couple pins, several screws and a cage around 4 vertebrae. After a long battle of Oxycoton and fentanyl as a dilutant for pain, the docs had this light bulb of an idea to place one of those pain stims under my ribs and hotwire my nerves so I don't feel the shooting pains any longer. The trial period seemed great, but the permanent fixture made matters very worse. I recommend if you haven't already done so ... contact other people w/ this apparatus jammed inside of them and get their opinions. Forums are everywhere out there, just Google it. They eventually had to take mine out because it was starting to really bring out my mean side. This is a more serious operation than the one to put this thing in. Only to later find out that more nerve damage has been caused. Fortunately for me one of the problems it created is in my left leg. If it were in my right, I would have already had my driving privileges revoked. Dude ... not trying to scare or talk you out of this treatment. I would just like you to explore ALL avenues if you haven't already. This is a serious “permanent " step that may have more side effect than the docs will tell.
reply: Miker ... I like many others here have had a couple back surgeries. Now I have a couple pins, several screws and a cage around 4 vertebrae. content: thanks for all your help guys, its been a long road since i was sent back from iraq up until now. i would prefer not to have this inside of me but my options have come down to this. hopefully i will regain pain free mobility and be able to function sexually. oh and to top off my day i had to have a wisdom tooth pulled after it cracked a few days ago, i guess when it rains it pours. at least i get to go home to the states for a month to recoup.

title: Spinal Stimulator

content: Sometimes, if ya have a bad tooth fixed, some of the achs and pains in other places go away. Studies have shown that infected teeth send inflamation throughout the body causing all kinds of problems, including heart trouble. I put up with several bad teeth for years because of not wanting to go to a dentist. During that time, at 55, I nearly died of a heart attack, yet I was in great physical shape. Well, I got the teeth worked on after having heart by-pass surgery. The dentist had me read a study that proved how bad teeth are linked to all kinds or irritating and even fatal problems. To put it simple, a bad tooth is just as dangerous as an infected appendix or a tumor. It can saturate the body over time with inflammation that can trigger all the wrong responses - arthritis, arteriosclerosis, inflammation of the heart sack, etc etc - not good. - - Wandering and Wondering

content: Miker, I am currently in the process of being medically dishcarged because of degenerative disk disease, after 15 years of service - and I only take meds when I need them! If you have a condition that will not be stable or get better (only worse) they will board you out. Just being honest. Try to start looking for a back-up plan now. You will receive disability that you can use while you attend school or something else. Good luck with everything. I wouldn't wish back pain on an enemy!
reply: Miker, I am currently in the process of being medically dishcarged because of degenerative disk disease, after 15 years of service - and I only take meds when I need them! title: Spinal Stimulator

content: heres my issue and question. i have been dubbed with severe testicular nerve damage and due to medication not working to resolve the issue, i have just completed my "trial stim period" for a spinal stimulator. with this they insert wire leads into the nerves around the spinal cord and through an external stimulator, they emit an electrical current to the nerves which blocks the pain from registering in the brain. i will soon be getting the permanant version which they implant under the skin to eleminate the external wiring. now to my question.. i love the army and wish to remain in and the doctor says that between 50-70% pain reduction is all that this will be able to provide and might need to remain on pain medication even after it is inserted. granted, this is a major improvement and i would take 5% and be happy if thats all it could do but again i am concerned that this will affect my career. i am wondering if anyone has this procedure and still remain active duty. i am aware of reclassing but a desk job really isnt my cup of tea. i was very physical in life until the pain was this severe back in september. the drawback is some doctors say to avoid physically demanding activities due to the leads pulling out of there anchoring, so sadly i dont know if surfing and snowboarding are out of my life now. if anyone can help it is deeply appreciated. thanks in advance.

Miker, Given what you've written here, it's entirely possible you'll be boarded out. You STILL have the condition that is causing you the pain, the stim only "short circuits" it. Plus the fact that strenuous activty CAN dislodge the electodes, it doesn't bode well. Good Luck, however.

content: well right now im on some pretty heavy stuff. i dont want to go to far into detail but one of them is morphine on a time release. others are your typical narcoticpain meds which i hate taking. i am really bummed out about this but luckily i have a great doctor whos goal is to be able to help me to lead a less painful life and "function" again if you catch my drift. im not going to lie, that gets me pretty depressed.. not suicidal just frustrated and right now im just taking it day by day.

title: Spinal Stimulator

content: Wow! - - I had back surgery while still in the military to correct a mashed disc and remove stalactite-like bone spurs which were digging into my sciatic nerves, causing me severe pain 24/7 and robbing me the use of my right leg (as well as any desire to go on living). The surgery, done arthroscopically, left about a 2 inch scar in the small of my back, required no bolts, screws or plates, and has completely free me of pain in that region, while restoring all use of my legs - - I remained 100% in the military, taking on not less, but more of a load. I have a son who has gone through an almost identical situation, and he is still on active duty - - I now have a lot of upper back pain between the shoulder blades because of similar problems. Doctors are less enthusiastic about surgery these days, so I do 8 arthritis tylenol a day - - The back surgery, not the same as yours obviously, gave me back an active life and kept me fully capable in the military. It did the same for my son. Both of us had nerves being crushed by a combination of sports-caused exertion/injury and bone spurs...both of which could be corrected with minimal surgery - - Maybe you? Wandering and Wondering
reply: Wow! - - I had back surgery while still in the military to correct a mashed disc and remove stalactite-like bone spurs which were digging into my sciatic nerves, causing me severe pain 24/7 and robbing me the use of my right leg (as well as any desire to go on living). The surgery, done arthroscopically, left about a 2 inch scar in the small of my back, required no bolts, screws or plates, and has completely free me of pain in that region, while restoring all use of my legs - - I remained 100% in the military, taking on not less, but more of a load. I have a son who has gone through an almost identical situation, and he is still on active duty - - I now have a lot of upper back pain between the shoulder blades because of similar problems. Doctors are less enthusiastic about surgery these days, so I do 8 arthritis tylenol a day - - The back surgery, not the same as yours obviously, gave me back an active life and kept me fully capable in the military. It did the same for my son. Both of us had nerves being crushed by a combination of sports-caused exertion/injury and bone spurs...both of which could be corrected with minimal surgery - - Maybe you? Wandering and Wondering

content: 88miker - If your physician and company commander agree that your condition/situation requires complex case management and will, in general, take about 6 months or more to resolve, then you can be recommended for transfer into a Warrior Transition Unit (WTU). The physician has to write a memo, the Company Commander has to complete a functional assessment, plus some other assorted paperwork, then it's all sent for review and possible assignment/attachment to a WTU near you. Being assigned/attached to a WTU is NOT a one-way ticket out. The idea of a WTU is to allow Soldiers to concentrate on healing and recovering maximum function. Being at maximum possible function can mean returning to duty (same MOS), MEB, PEB or MMRB for reclass. If you are having difficulty performing your job, and if you are having difficulty making medical appointments because of job requirements (or interference), then you might want to look into the WTU as an option that can give you a really good shot at staying in.
reply: 88miker - If your physician and company commander agree that your condition/situation requires complex case management and will, in general, take about 6 months or more to resolve, then you can be recommended for transfer into a Warrior Transition Unit (WTU). The physician has to write a memo, the Company Commander has to complete a functional assessment, plus some other assorted paperwork, then it's all sent for review and possible assignment/attachment to a WTU near you. Being assigned/attached to a WTU is NOT a one-way ticket out. The idea of a WTU is to allow Soldiers to concentrate on healing and recovering maximum function. Being at maximum possible function can mean returning to duty (same MOS), MEB, PEB or MMRB for reclass. If you are having difficulty performing your job, and if you are having difficulty making medical appointments because of job requirements (or interference), then you might want to look into the WTU as an option that can give you a really good shot at staying in.

title: Spinal Stimulator

content: Miker, Sorry to hear about your condition. I had a compression fracture to L3 vertebrae while in. I was down for 6 weeks. I was fine for awhile, but a few years later it started agrivating me. It got to the point where I was unable to do daily PT. I was waived from that but still had to perform the biannual PT Test. I progressively became slower and slower, but still not failing. Even then there was one doc that tried to get me Med Boarded. I was REAL lucky that I had 18 1/2 years in at the time he tried this. I was able to retire with my 20, but had to fight for it. I can't tell you what will happen to you as each case is different, but good luck. George P.S. - You may have already asked (and probably don't want to hear this) but have you asked the dreaded question of what your condition would be if they were removed. I know, I know, not what you want to hear. Just a question though...which is more important to you right now, the twins or your career...food for thought.

Even then there was one doc that tried to get me Med Boarded. I was REAL lucky that I had 18 1/2 years in at the time he tried this. I was able to retire with my 20, but had to fight for it. I can't tell you what will happen to you as each case is different, but good luck. George P.S. - You may have already asked (and probably don't want to hear this) but have you asked the dreaded question of what your condition would be if they were removed. I know, I know, not what you want to hear. Just a question though...which is more important to you right now, the twins or your career...food for thought.
title: Spinal Stimulator

content: Miker ... I like many others here have had a couple back surgeries. Now I have a couple pins, several screws and a cage around 4 vertebrae. After a long battle of Oxycoton and fentanyl as a dilutant for pain, the docs had this light bulb of an idea to place one of those pain stims under my ribs and hotwire my nerves so I don't feel the shooting pains any longer. The trial period seemed great, but the permanent fixture made matters very worse. I recommend if you haven't already done so ... contact other people w/ this apparatus jammed inside of them and get their opinions. Forums are everywhere out there, just Google it. They eventually had to take mine out because it was starting to really bring out my mean side. This is a more serious operation than the one to put this thing in. Only to later find out that more nerve damage has been caused. Fortunately for me one of the problems it created is in my left leg. If it were in my right, I would have already had my driving privileges revoked. Dude ... not trying to scare or talk you out of this treatment. I would just like you to explore ALL avenues if you haven't already. This is a serious “permanent " step that may have more side effect than the docs will tell.
reply: Miker ... I like many others here have had a couple back surgeries. Now I have a couple pins, several screws and a cage around 4 vertebrae. After a long battle of Oxycoton and fentanyl as a dilutant for pain, the docs had this light bulb of an idea to place one of those pain stims under my ribs and hotwire my nerves so I don't feel the shooting pains any longer. reply: thanks for all your help guys, its been a long road since i was sent back from iraq up until now. i would prefer not to have this inside of me but my options have come down to this. hopefully i will regain pain free mobility and be able to function sexually. oh and to top off my day i had to have a wisdom tooth pulled after it cracked a few days ago, i guess when it rains it pours. at least i get to go home to the states for a month to recoup.

content: Sometimes, if ya have a bad tooth fixed, some of the achs and pains in other places go away. Studies have shown that infected teeth send inflamation throughout the body causing all kinds of problems, including heart trouble. I put up with several bad teeth for years because of not wanting to go to a dentist. During that time, at 55, I nearly died of a heart attack, yet I was in great physical shape. Well, I got the teeth worked on after having heart by-pass surgery. The dentist had me read a study that proved how bad teeth are linked to all kinds or irritating and even fatal problems. To put it simple, a bad tooth is just as dangerous as an infected appendix or a tumor. It can saturate the body over time with inflammation that can trigger all the wrong responses - arthritis, arteriosclerosis, inflammation of the heart sack, etc etc - not good. - - Wandering and Wondering

content: Miker, I am currently in the process of being medically dishcarged because of degenerative disk disease, after 15 years of service - and I only take meds when I need them! If you have a condition that will not be stable or get better (only worse) they will board you out. Just being honest. Try to start looking for a back-up plan now. You will receive disability that you can use while you attend school or something else. Good luck with everything. I wouldn't wish back pain on an enemy!

content: i used to be a civilian helicopter pilot, but im afraid i cant go back to that because of the meds.. i am thinking of using the gi bill and going to nursing school and getting into a career that is stable even in an economical crisis.
